messageBody:
Soundex/Metaphone are methods for matching strings which 'sound similar'
(the wikipedia articles for both seem quite good).

They work by producing a digest of a string which can then be compared
to other digests, any two digests in a set distance 'match'.

For example, the words 'I' and 'eye' should have the same digest and
therefore a distance of 0.
In a more or less ideal system 'Log' and 'Dog' would have a distance of 1.
As would 'there' and 'their'.

The big problem is creating the digests, we have to guess how a word
would be said from it's spelling.
I don't think I need to point out how difficult that is in English using
Latin.

Soundex is antiquated and never really worked anyway, the digests it
produced were the first letter of the word followed by a number.
The current favourite for sound-alike searches is an improved Double
Metaphone, the digests that it produces look _very_ like APA, IPA.

The point is that Quikscript (and Shavian) allow us to skip the digest
stage since the characters are essentially pre-digested for us, in fact
they're far more accurate than Metaphone could ever produce since we
_know_ how it should sound.

The big advantage is in terms of dictionaries and spell checkers.
In most cases the distance between an en_GB, an en_US and an en_CA word
should be 1 or 2 (although you may need to increase the distance for
words with lots of vowels).
Sound-alike searching is really the only kind of search you can do when
there is no correct spelling of a word.

This is one of the reasons I'm so set on encoding the 'meaning' rather
than the appearance of characters.

Not having OSX I can't try the moose for my self but it looks like fun.

Please don't think that I (and I'm sure everyone else) don't appreciate
thrashing out the issues, hopefully we can come up with a encoding which
everyone will find useful.

Michael Everson wrote:
> At 21:06 +0100 2007-05-29, amd64_hacker wrote:
>> True, but it isn't just glyph shapes either - it's function also.
>> The French 'u' and English 'u' are both part of the Latin alphabet.
>> Cyrillic Capital Letter A and Latin Capital Letter A are all but
>> identical in appearance but have different code points.
>
> And there are reasons why, which don't apply to a proposed
> disunification of QS from Shavian, as far as I can see so far.
>
>> One of the really, really nice side effects of
>> Quikscript/Shavian/phonic-alphabets-in-general is that they don't need
>> as much work to create soundex/metaphone type functions for.
>
> I don't know what that is. Or those are. But that is a higher-level
> protocol which deals with an underlying encoding, I take it.
>
>> The difficult bit, converting letters to sounds, has already been done
>> for you and at that point it basically boils down to an edit distance
>> search.
>
> Yes, well, I remember making the Talking Moose speak Irish. Talking
> Moose orthography is an orthography that can be read by some software
> which reads character sequences. It was never designed for Irish. You
> could get it to work though.
>
>> If we work purely on the appearance we lose the phonic information and a
>> lot of ease of use.
>
> "Phonic"?
>
>> We can consolidate Shavian and Quikscript characters which are identical
>> but we shouldn't throw away all that extra information/functionality for
>> the sake of a few code points.
>
> The Universal Character Set is not really concerned about "a few code
> points". But the encoding of QS must be in accordance with The Way We
> Actually Do Things. Please take note that John Cowan and I are here
> because we want to help you. If we disagree with disunifying QS from
> Shavian it's because that's what's going to get you the characters
> that you need.
>
>> Especially considering the main use of soundex/metaphone is in spell
>> checkers which would probably be even more useful in Quikscript than
>> they are in Latin.
>
> Could you explain what this means?
